body:
Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1432/

Thanks for the great review @dusenberrymw!

1) For the mappings, a script is being mapped to a Java class, which is uppercased, while functions are being mapped to methods on the Java class, which by convention are lowercased. However, this is a Java convention and is not required. If allowing uppercased methods seems like it feels right from a usability perspective for data scientists, we can definitely do that easily.
2) I was attempting to create Scala-style minimalism, but something like _docs/__docs/_source/__source is definitely very easy to do and certainly clearer.
3) Currently the contents for each class are being pulled from the jar file. The file system is not overriding the content of the jar file. 1) and 2) are trivial but 3) is a bit more work but certainly achievable. We should be able to make script and method contents dynamic but the function signatures probably need to stay static due to java classloading issues. It might be good to do 3) as a separate PR.

For (1), in particular, I was thinking it would be nice to follow the case of the function *parameters* and return variables defined in the DML.  So for `val dummy = clf.generate_dummy_data()`, I would expect to be able to use `dummy.X`, `dummy.Y`, `dummy.Hin`, etc., just as defined in the DML file.

For (2), I agree that the minimalism is great for the current solution.  Let's get some feedback from others as to whether minimalism or verbosity would be better here, as I'm not even completely sure one way or another.  For myself, I understand the current syntax, but I'm just not sure about others.  If we do go with the more verbose way, I think two underscores would be needed, as many of the DML functions will have underscores in the name, and thus a single underscore may just look like another DML function.

For (3) yeah the ultimate ideal would be realtime, dynamic generation of everything.  Of course that looks pretty hard, so I think keeping the function signatures static is fine.  Allowing for dynamic function bodies would definitely be extremely useful and needed.
LGTM :+1:
@nakul02 Have you been able to successfully run this?  It would be good to merge if it is able to target multi-GPU.
It seems to be a bit unstable with GPU. Let me debug these and let you know.

Updated 1) and 2). The following now works:
```
import org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext._
val ml = new MLContext(spark)
val clf = ml.nn.examples.Mnist_lenet
val dummy = clf.generate_dummy_data
val dummyVal = clf.generate_dummy_data
val params = clf.train(dummy.X, dummy.Y, dummyVal.X, dummyVal.Y, dummy.C, dummy.Hin, dummy.Win, 1)
val probs = clf.predict(dummy.X, dummy.C, dummy.Hin, dummy.Win, params.W1, params.b1, params.W2, params.b2, params.W3, params.b3, params.W4, params.b4)
val perf = clf.eval(probs, dummy.Y)

clf.eval__docs
clf.eval__source
```

I'll try to have a look next week. In the meantime, you might want to revisit the integration approach - the large number of files you had to modify is already an indicator that this is probably not a good approach. 

It should be fairly simply: create a single static call which dispatches between matrix block (which should not call libnative at all) and libnative, initialize once, and call it for each matrix multiplication that potentially calls native BLAS - for example for compressed matrix blocks this is never required.

@mboehm7 This approach allows the matrix multiplication on remote executor to respect the configuration flag `native.blas`. Since the configuration is not sent to the executor, not sure how single static call will enable that. But, we can discuss this next week after you have had chance to look at it :)

Not working as despite    <native.blas>true</native.blas> in SystemML-config.xml, another env var disables it.

17/05/03 09:07:33 WARN utils.NativeHelper: Using internal Java BLAS as native BLAS support is disabled by the environment variable 'SYSTEMML_BLAS='.

@deroneriksson Awesome, that LGTM.  Let's merge this, and then follow-up with (3) in a separate PR.  Also, for (3), I noticed that `"scripts/"` is being prepended to the script paths that are generated, so that causes those files to always be sourced from the JAR.  Interestingly, since files like `mnist_lenet.dml` import `nn/../..`, I believe the `nn` files would be loaded dynamically for invocations of functions from `mnist_lenet.dml`.

Adding dynamic loading of DML script content sounds like it could be very useful during DML development. Doing this in a separate PR sounds great.

I'm about to be away from any computers until Sunday. Feel free to merge this if you think it would be useful during the next few days. Otherwise, I will merge most likely on Sunday or Monday. I'm a little apprehensive to merge and then all of a sudden not be available in case there are any issues.
cc @mboehm7 Can you review this fix for the datatype conversion issue?  I'm also waiting for the full testing with Jenkins.

Thanks for reviewing @frreiss ! I will address your comments, rebase, and update the PR!

I'm still not convinced by this PR because the experimental results were non-conclusive (especially in comparison to simple rewrites), it does not nicely fit into our the architecture of memory management (without unnecessary over-provisioning), it unnecessarily differs from R syntax, and the CP batch iterator might actually create more evictions in the presence of memory pressure. So I would recommend to not rush this in.

Example:
```
import org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext._
import org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext.ScriptFactory._
val ml = new MLContext(spark)
dml("a=1;x=a+1;y=x+1").out(scala.List("x", "y")).execute
dml("a=1;x=a+1;y=x+1").out(scala.Seq("x", "y")).execute
dml("a=1;x=a+1;y=x+1").out(java.util.Arrays.asList("x","y")).execute
```

cc @dusenberrymw

Example:
```
spark-shell --executor-memory 4G --driver-memory 4G --driver-class-path=target/SystemML.jar

import org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext._
val ml = new MLContext(spark)
val mnist_lenet = ml.nn.examples.Mnist_lenet
ml.setStatistics(true)
val data = mnist_lenet.generate_dummy_data
ml.setStatistics(false)
val data = mnist_lenet.generate_dummy_data
```

https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1459/

This touches upon a broader question, i.e., should all explain/stats output go to stdout or the logs? Just to give the history: We had deployments, where SystemML was called in a separate process and writing to stdout would clog up the stdout queue if nobody is reading from it. Hence all output except print/stop goes to the logs. That's also the reason why our scripts have options to write any debug output to text files instead of printing it. However, nowadays such deployments are rather uncommon and we could reconsider this in general.

When working in an interactive environment such as Spark Shell, outputting to stdout I feel is highly preferrable. I'm less certain about other environments.

As an illustration, the above example generates:
```
Welcome to
      ____              __
     / __/__  ___ _____/ /__
    _\ \/ _ \/ _ `/ __/  '_/
   /___/ .__/\_,_/_/ /_/\_\   version 2.1.0
      /_/
         
Using Scala version 2.11.8 (Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM, Java 1.8.0_60)
Type in expressions to have them evaluated.
Type :help for more information.

scala> import org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext._
import org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext._

scala> val ml = new MLContext(spark)

Welcome to Apache SystemML!

ml: org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext.MLContext = org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext.MLContext@4930213b

scala> val mnist_lenet = ml.nn.examples.Mnist_lenet
mnist_lenet: org.apache.sysml.scripts.nn.examples.Mnist_lenet =
Inputs:
None

Outputs:
None

scala> ml.setStatistics(true)

scala> val data = mnist_lenet.generate_dummy_data
SystemML Statistics:
Total elapsed time:		0.115 sec.
Total compilation time:		0.000 sec.
Total execution time:		0.115 sec.
Number of compiled Spark inst:	0.
Number of executed Spark inst:	0.
Cache hits (Mem, WB, FS, HDFS):	3/0/0/0.
Cache writes (WB, FS, HDFS):	5/0/0.
Cache times (ACQr/m, RLS, EXP):	0.000/0.000/0.001/0.000 sec.
HOP DAGs recompiled (PRED, SB):	0/0.
HOP DAGs recompile time:	0.000 sec.
Spark ctx create time (lazy):	0.000 sec.
Spark trans counts (par,bc,col):0/0/0.
Spark trans times (par,bc,col):	0.000/0.000/0.000 secs.
Total JIT compile time:		0.067 sec.
Total JVM GC count:		15.
Total JVM GC time:		0.815 sec.
Heavy hitter instructions (name, time, count):
-- 1) 	rand 	0.103 sec 	2	
-- 2) 	round 	0.007 sec 	1	
-- 3) 	ctableexpand 	0.004 sec 	1	
-- 4) 	createvar 	0.001 sec 	5	
-- 5) 	seq 	0.000 sec 	1	
-- 6) 	rmvar 	0.000 sec 	5	
-- 7) 	cpvar 	0.000 sec 	2	
-- 8) 	assignvar 	0.000 sec 	3	

data: org.apache.sysml.scripts.nn.examples.mnist_lenet.Generate_dummy_data_output =
X (Matrix): MatrixObject: scratch_space//_p60985_192.168.1.104//_t0/temp0_0, [1024 x 784, nnz=802816, blocks (1000 x 1000)], binaryblock, dirty
Y (Matrix): MatrixObject: scratch_space//_p60985_192.168.1.104//_t0/temp4_4, [1024 x 10, nnz=1024, blocks (1000 x 1000)], binaryblock, dirty
C (long): 1
Hin (long): 28
Win (long): 28

scala> ml.setStatistics(false)

scala> val data = mnist_lenet.generate_dummy_data
data: org.apache.sysml.scripts.nn.examples.mnist_lenet.Generate_dummy_data_output =
X (Matrix): MatrixObject: scratch_space//_p60985_192.168.1.104//_t0/temp5_5, [1024 x 784, nnz=802816, blocks (1000 x 1000)], binaryblock, dirty
Y (Matrix): MatrixObject: scratch_space//_p60985_192.168.1.104//_t0/temp9_9, [1024 x 10, nnz=1024, blocks (1000 x 1000)], binaryblock, dirty
C (long): 1
Hin (long): 28
Win (long): 28

scala>
```

We could even potentially make it configurable whether the output goes to stdout and/or logging.

Even `explain` via `MLContext` [is printed to](https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/api/mlcontext/ScriptExecutor.java#L188)`System.out`. 

Would it make sense to provide an extra method - `ml.showStatistics()` - that would print out the statistics to stdout and by default it could print to log4j?
Until a few days ago, statistics via MLContext also printed to System.out. This PR is just reverting to that behavior.

BTW @mboehm7 brings up a good point about statistics/explain and how they should be handled. This probably will be an issue to address in the consolidated compilation chain, where statistics/explain can potentially be configurable based on how SystemML is being run or configurable by user preference.
@nakul02 If we make it configurable via MLContext, I feel strongly that the default should be stdout.

@gweidner @lresende 
Luciano noticed on commit mailing list that we may need to revert to the previous copyright.

I believe he may be right:
We use JQuery 1.12.0:
https://github.com/jquery/jquery/tree/1.12.0/external/sizzle

JQuery 1.12.0 uses Sizzle 2.2.1:
https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/1.12.0/external/sizzle/dist/sizzle.js

Sizzle 2.2.1 uses:
https://github.com/jquery/sizzle/blob/2.2.1/LICENSE.txt
"Copyright jQuery Foundation and other contributors, https://jquery.org/"

Notice master and 2.2.1 copyrights are different. Good catch Luciano!

https://github.com/jquery/sizzle/blob/master/LICENSE.txt
https://github.com/jquery/sizzle/blob/2.2.1/LICENSE.txt

Cool, I will go ahead and merge.

BTW, I like the idea of potentially making the output of stats/explain configurable in the near future.
Actually, it looks like there were test failures on Jenkins. I will investigate.

Thank you for catching - I've switched back to jQuery copyright in following commit:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/commit/2fbed1f1ab3b9d366fbad35204a0d33a20d33226
Yeah stdout should be the default, but we should definitely think about a simple configuration, such as an `ml.setOutputType(...)`.

https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1465/

Please drop the redundant time in nanoseconds. These heavy hitter instructions show aggregates - so anything below millisecond granularity is pretty much irrelevant. We measure times internally at nanosecond granularity because you might have billions of small operations that might take less than a millisecond. Also, please collapse the header to a single line.

@mboehm7 @dusenberrymw 
I'll restore the old behavior for all parts of the project except the new MLContext.

I would recommend to keep the APIs consistent. What was the motivation for showing the times in nano second resolution?
sorry - I didn't get a chance to try it out yet, but I'll look into it in the next days.

Can an Admin verify this patch?
Pinging @niketanpansare, @dusenberrymw, @iyounus

This new formatting is good, but do we want to consider the possibility of printing out the heavy hitters in different formats? One that is friendly to view on stdout (the way this PR does it) and another that is friendly to copy-pasting into a spreadsheet (tab separated)?

@deroneriksson  - having different outputs for different resolutions (less than 0.001s) might be confusing. If the output format is the same, I can immediately look for change in performance info in iterative experiments at exactly the same (relative) location on my screen.

Hi @mboehm7 

My motivation to add ns display was for situations where times are very short (short 'hello world' types of DML scripts), since it can feel a little disconcerting to me to see instructions that take '0.000' time, such as:
```
Heavy hitter instructions:
 #  Instruction  Time(s)   Time(ns)  Count
 1  toString       0.002  1,618,379      2
 2  *2             0.001  1,422,184      2
 3  createvar      0.001    966,002      4
 4  sinit          0.000    339,480      2
 5  print          0.000    319,485      4
 6  rmvar          0.000     90,669     13
 7  +              0.000     17,325      1
 8  -              0.000     10,639      1
 9  assignvar      0.000      9,481      3
10  *              0.000      8,223      1
```

However, I agree that for most situations, the ns display is irrelevant and probably distracting.
```
Heavy hitter instructions:
 #  Instruction  Time(s)  Count
 1  wdivmm         2.324    923
 2  +*             0.937   2749
 3  *              0.746   1876
 4  tak+*          0.448    913
 5  uasqk+         0.402    923
 6  -*             0.292    913
 7  rand           0.065      9
 8  ba+*           0.057      1
 9  createvar      0.025   5554
10  ctable         0.019      1
```

I added a check to only display the ns column in the (rare) occasions where the times are very very small. Perhaps that might be a good compromise?

@nakul02 @mboehm7 
It sounds like ns display causes more issues than it solves. I'll remove it.
Nice.  For `DRIVER` mode, will we be able to setup MLContext to work without needing Spark?  I.e. could we simply use SystemML as a single Scala/Java program via MLContext?
Can an Admin verify this patch?

Currently a lot of the primary classes in the API (MLContext, MLContextUtil, MLContextConversionUtil, Matrix, MLResults, etc) utilize Spark classes. We could probably do something such as create parent classes without the Spark class references to allow MLContext usage without Spark, although of course it could quite possibly be more difficult than that.
